content:
I understand your perspective. It is true that architecture has the power to evoke and shape emotions, and Le Corbusier's functionalist approach may not resonate with everyone's personal aesthetic preferences. However, it's worth noting that Le Corbusier also believed that architecture should be responsive to human needs and emotions, despite his emphasis on functionality. He believed that good design should be oriented towards the wellbeing of its occupants and should create a sense of order and harmony.

Moreover, it's important to understand that architecture is an art form, and like any art form, it can create strong emotional responses in different ways. Some may consider Le Corbusier's designs cold or sterile, while others may admire their clarity and simplicity. Beauty is subjective and can be interpreted in many ways. 

That being said, Le Corbusier's emphasis on functionality and efficiency has had a lasting impact on modern architecture. His work laid the foundation for many subsequent architectural movements, including modernism, minimalism, and even sustainable design. So while his approach may not be universally admired for its emotional impact, it has undeniably contributed to the evolution of architecture and its relationship to society.
